title: Welcome
text:
Three little beans painting the same fruit basket, but with diverging results
Welcome! üßô
This presentation, ‚ÄúReproducible Research: Every little helps‚Äù, offers a brief overview of key ideas and insights I‚Äôve gathered from the literature‚Äîalong with a few lessons I‚Äôve learned along the way that may aid some of you.

title: Welcome
text:
Background of the presentation
This presentation was designed for a weekly student seminar series at the LBBE laboratory, organised by the Student Seminar team (most members of which are part of Les Pinsons Migrateurs). It originates from discussions with many of my fellow colleagues about reproducible research‚Äîits whys and hows‚Äîand from the observation that a seminar on this topic has strong potential to spark rich and meaningful discussions.
This seminar is a fusion of two earlier contributions: my very first hands-on workshop held in February 2025 for the LIEC (Metz), and a previous presentation given in September 2025 for the LEHNA (Lyon). You can explore the full materials and corresponding websites here: workshop and presentation.
Recognising the ongoing need to share knowledge about reproducible research‚Äîand the desire to discuss it with non-permanent researchers‚ÄîI decided to organise this session as a way to contribute what I know on the topic (or what I think I know üëΩ). While I don‚Äôt claim to be an expert, every little helps. My hope is that this seminar sparks enough interest to encourage others to explore and strive toward more reproducible, transparent, and accessible research practices.

title: Welcome
text:
Description
The presentation focuses on introducing the what, where, when, and how of reproducible research. We‚Äôll explore the benefits of working reproducibly‚Äîboth for others and for ourselves‚Äîexamine the factors that limit or discourage reproducible practices, and discuss practical, incremental solutions for becoming more reproducible in our work. There will be some interactive elements scattered around the presentation. A seminar on this subject gains value through interaction and engagement from the audience, so I‚Äôve woven discussion questions throughout the presentation to encourage exchange and reflection.

title: Reproducible Research
section: How important is it? Well, quite important
text:
How important is it? Well, quite important
 



Anyone (with a similar level of skills) should be able to do reproduce your research and benefit from it
Funders (e.g., ANR) and journals now require data and code accessibility, which aligns with the growing open-science movement
If I keep my data and code, I have a competitive advantage
If I share my data and code, my work will gain more visibility (and citations üòé)

title: Reproducible Research
text:
Advantages
 


It obliges you to verify your work (by sharing both docs, data and code)
Your future self will thank you (you‚Äôll be much more productive)
Your collaborators too
By ensuring reproducibility, you reinforce your credibility and reputation
Employers increasingly value reproducible research skills
Reproducibility fosters trust in scientific progress and accelerates it
